<p><strong>Over the course of 2022,</strong> the global private markets industry experienced a slowdown in fundraising and deal making because of rising interest rates and other factors. Despite the rocky year, private equity and alternative investments (hereafter PE) and alternative investments remain significant in the global economy. The industry now manages $11.7 trillion in assets, up from $8.0 trillion the previous year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d263c0d8-011d-430a-a7cd-46b7dcc15a87"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d263c0d8-011d-430a-a7cd-46b7dcc15a87" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/mckinseys-private-markets-annual-review-2023">McKinsey Global Private Markets Review: Private markets turn down the volume</a>, McKinsey, March 21, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The financial power of PE reinforces the importance of understanding the composition of its talent, particularly the professionals who decide how this capital is deployed.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This report is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/pontus-averstad">Pontus Averstad</a>, <a href="/our-people/fredrik-dahlqvist">Fredrik Dahlqvist</a>, Eitan Lefkowitz, <a href="/our-people/alexandra-nee">Alexandra Nee</a>, <a href="/our-people/gary-pinshaw">Gary Pinshaw</a>, <a href="/our-people/david-quigley">David Quigley,</a> and Mohammed Shafi, representing views from McKinseys Private Equity & Principal Investors Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Building on <a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2022">McKinseys 2022 report</a>, this years report examines the diversity of talent in PE firms, which we will refer to simply as PE firms. Specifically, we examine the gender breakdown in every region in our study and look at ethnicity and race in the United States and Canada (for more on the research and analysis, see sidebar About the study).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Female black corporate professional stares at camera" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/dei-private-markets-1128213401-1536x1536_offset300.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-7"><p><div><em>We are excited to invite Private Equity/Alternative Investing firms and Institutional Investors to participate in McKinsey & Companys State of Diversity in Global Private Markets 2024 study! This annual study is the largest and most comprehensive study of diversity in private market firms globally. </em></div></p></div></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/private-capital/how-we-help-clients/the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Sign up here</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>This years report centers on the following core research objectives:</p>
<ol>
    <li>understand the current state of gender diversity globally, and ethnic and racial diversity in the US and Canada, for the PE industryspecifically, which types of firms are leading and lagging on diverse talent</li>
    <li>how institutional investors influence the representation of diverse talent at PE firms, and the extent to which diversity matters to them</li>
    <li>highlighting the specific challenges facing different minority groups and identifying actions that can increase the diversity of talent in PE firms</li>
</ol>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the study</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>In our second annual report, we build on the insights and findings from our inaugural report in 2022, as well as on prior McKinsey research on diversity in the workplace. This research explores diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) in the global private-markets industry, with a focus on private equity and alternative investment firms (PE) and institutional investors. We aim to make this the largest study of gender diversity and ethnic and racial diversity in the global private markets industry.</p>
<p>This years survey covers 66 discrete PE firms and institutional investors around the world. We also conducted interviews with several industry leaders to supplement the survey data we received from their firms. Participating firms directly employ more than 60,000 people globally and range from megafirms with more than $100 billion in assets under management (AUM) to smaller funds with less than $5 billion in AUM. Collectively, participating PE firms manage more than $6 trillion, and participating institutional investors manage more than $5 trillion in AUM.</p>
<p>Given the limitations of data collection, this report largely focuses on gender diversity globally and ethnic and racial diversity in private market firms with offices in the United States and Canada. We recognize there are several other categories that contribute to employee diversity and hope to broaden the categories we examine in future research as private market firms collect more diversity data on their employee base.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>This report finds encouraging signs of progress in recent years. Diversity on investment committees (ICs) has ticked up, and the reporting of diversity metrics to institutional investors continues to grow.</p>
<p>Still, gaps remain, particularly regarding gender diversity in senior investing roles and uneven rates of progress for different ethnic and racial groups across roles and regions, and types of firms. Given the current pace of progress, it will be several decades before the PE industry achieves gender parity at the principal and managing-director levels.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Given the current pace of progress, it will be several decades before the PE industry achieves gender parity at the principal and managing-director levels.</p></blockquote></div>
<h2>A global view on gender diversity in private equity and alternative investing</h2>
<p>There is a popular assumption that PE is dominated by men, but the evidence reveals a more nuanced reality. As we noted last year, PE firms have almost achieved gender parity globally at the entry level. At the end of 2022, 48 percent of all entry-level roles in PE were held by women.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Job levels in private equity</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>The language we use to classify jobs in private equity (PE) has not changed from last year's. The six levels we identify apply to PE jobs in investing, operational, and other noninvesting functions. For most of these levels, we include multiple possible job titles. In descending order of seniority, the roles are as follows:</p>
<p>L1. C-level executives or fund heads. We refer to this level as the C-level or C-suite.</p>
<p>L2. Managing directors or partners. We refer to jobs at this level as managing directors.</p>
<p>L3. Principals, directors, or senior vice presidents. We refer to jobs at this level as principals.</p>
<p>L4. Vice presidents or senior managers. We refer to jobs at this level as VPs.</p>
<p>L5. Associates or managers. We refer to jobs at this level as associates.</p>
<p>L6. Entry level roles.</p>
<p>For the sake of simplicity, we will refer to each level with only one title.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>However, women in PE are still underrepresented in leadership positions, with only 20 percent representation in managing-director roles (for more on job levels, see sidebar Job levels in private equity). As Kelley King, senior vice president and chief DEI officer at HarbourVest, explained, Identifying and attracting early-career diverse talent is not as challenging as finding later-career talent. As you ascend higher in the organization, the more patient and intentional firms need to be to reap the benefits of their DEI efforts.</p>
<h3>Women are well represented in most noninvesting roles, but gender parity remains distant in investing and operating roles</h3>
<p>Disaggregating the data into investing, operating, and other noninvesting roles (the latter of which we will refer to as noninvesting roles) reveals that women hold only 33 percent of entry-level investing roles, compared with 44 percent of operating roles and 59 percent of noninvesting roles at that level. Women are also underrepresented at the managing-director level (L2), with only 15 percent of managing-director-level investing roles (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex1-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Women are more represented in non-investing roles than in operating and investing roles at every level." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex1-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<!-- -->
<p>Women in PE have made modest gains in investing roles over the course of 2022. The share of C-suite roles held by women globally increased by 3.5 percentage points over the past year to 17 percent at the end of 2022. Similarly, womens representation in post-MBA investing associate (L5) roles improved by three percentage points. However, gender diversity at the managing-director level remained constant.</p>
<p>Women in PE are slightly less represented in operating roles than in investing roles, with women holding only 25 percent of all operating roles. Notably, women in operations have achieved gender parity at the associate level (L5), with 52 percent of roles. However, gender diversity undergoes a steep decline at higher levels, with women holding just 21 percent of managing-director-level (L2) operating jobs.</p>
<p>Progress is generally cause for optimism, but if the pace of progress doesnt accelerate, the path to gender parity in the industry will be long. At the current rate of progress, reaching gender parity in investing roles at the managing-director level (L2) would take more than six decades. Achieving gender parity at the principal level (L3) would take more than three decades (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Depending on the level, global gender parity in investing roles may take multiple decades to achieve." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>While these numbers are sobering, the outlook is significantly brighter at the entry level. Based on current figures, the industry could reach gender parity at the analyst level (L6) and associate level (L5) within the next decade.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>At the current rate of progress, reaching gender parity in investing roles at the managing-director level (L2) would take more than six decades.</p></blockquote></div>
<h3>Promotion rates: Women in investing face a longer road</h3>
<p>In demanding PE careers, women find themselves navigating a longer route to reach the same milestones as their male colleagues. At almost every level, women in investing roles are promoted at significantly lower rates than men. <span style="line-height:110%">Globally, men in investing roles are about 50 percent more likely, on average, to be promoted than their female colleagues,</span> a trend that persists across all levels in investing roles (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex3-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="At every level, women in investing roles are less likely than men to be promoted." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex3-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The largest gap affects promotions into the principal level (L3), with men 2.75 times more likely than women to be promoted. One contributor to this disparity may be limited sponsorship and mentorship for women at the vice president (VP) level. As the head of talent for a North American PE fund put it, At that [middle] level is where we find a number of ethnic minorities and women who have really felt like the levels they are at have a sticky floor. They found that its really hard to get that next promotion. They feel left out. They havent received the kind of mentorship and the kind of apprenticeship that theyre really going to need or the sponsorship to get promoted.</p>
<p>The road to meaningful progress will likely be long. However, theres a bright spot: the promotion gap at the managing-director level (L2) shrank in 2022.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Globally, men in investing roles are about 50 percent more likely, on average, to be promoted than their female colleagues.</p></blockquote></div>
<h3>Significant differences in representation between leading and lagging firms</h3>
<p>Some firms have made noteworthy strides on the diversity of their talent pool, so much so that the industrys global average of women in 15 percent of investing managing-director roles looks paltry by comparison. Leading firms had women in 45 percent of managing-director (L2) roles as the end of 2022. These firms also had significantly higher proportions of women at every level and overall had women in 38 percent of their investing roles, compared with the global average of 25 percent.</p>
<p>Interestingly, firms that were leaders in gender diversity (as indicated by relatively high proportions of women in managing-director roles) also retained women at higher rates than the industry average. However, firms that lagged on gender diversity showed significantly higher attrition in 2022 among women in investing. These firms in our sample did not have women in managing-director (L2) investing roles and had only 17 percent women in investing roles overall compared to the 25 percent global benchmark. Furthermore, these firms attrition rates for women in investing were 1.7 times higher, at 27 percent, than the global average over the course of 2022 (Exhibit 4).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex4-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Globally, firms that lead in gender diversity at L2 also beat the industry benchmark for all investing roles." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex4-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>For investing roles, our findings suggest a correlation between the representation of women at the top and higher overall gender representation, as well as between lack of women at the top and their ability to retain women at all levels of investing roles.</p>
<p>Our findings on gender diversity over time also highlight the feasibility of substantial progress when decision makers deploy effective strategies. Indeed, the results of our study show that not all PE firms are equal when it comes to cultures that support diverse talent.</p>
<h3>Different regions have different timelines to gender parity</h3>
<p>The timelines to achieving gender parity vary by region. For instance, despite advances, Europe still faces significant challenges related to womens representation at senior levels. At its current pace, Europe would require more than six decades to reach gender parity at senior levels.</p>
<p>By contrast, based on the rate of recent progress, the Americas are the furthest from achieving gender parity at middle and junior levels for investing roles. The situation is notably different in the AsiaPacific region, which has done the most to close the gender gap at middle and senior levels recently (Exhibit 5).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The time it will take for private equity to reach gender parity varies by region." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>A concerning trend has emerged over the past two years: gender representation has seen a minor decrease in the AsiaPacific region at the associate level (L5). Although this decline starts from a relatively high base, it indicates the need for ongoing efforts to maintain a diverse talent pipeline that can help the industry achieve gender parity.</p>
<h2>Ethnic and racial diversity in private equity</h2>
<p>Consistent with our past findings, ethnic and racial minorities in PE face similar underrepresentation as women. At nearly every level, investing roles have lower ethnic and racial diversity than noninvesting and operating-partner roles.</p>
<p>Our research data from the United States and Canada shows that ethnic and racial minorities represent only 20 percent of managing-director-level investing professionals (Exhibit 6). For context, people who identify as ethnic and racial minorities account for 30 percent of the Canadian population and 41 percent of the US population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c7b6d948-e527-4345-9f01-f05d84731f4f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c7b6d948-e527-4345-9f01-f05d84731f4f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">QuickFacts: United States population estimates, US Census Bureau, July 1, 2022; The Canadian census: A rich portrait of the country's religious and ethnocultural diversity, Statistics Canada, October 26, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> However, we found positive progress in ethnic and racial diversity in ICs in 2022. Ethnic and racial minorities represented 18 percent of investment committee members, nearly matching the ethnic and racial diversity of managing directors (L2) that year.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex6-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="As of 2022, the makeup of investment committees in the United States and Canada more closely reflect the diversity of managing directors." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex6-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The improvement in the diversity of talent in investment committees over the course of 2022 may be the result of new requirements for PE firms to disclose C-suite- and investment-committee-level diversity data to prospective investors. The chief HR officer of a midsize PE firm headquartered in North America referred to this as a standard part of the due diligence questionnaire these days.</p>
<p>Investment professionals who identify as White held 70 percent of all investing roles and 80 percent of managing-director roles. As of 2022, White men made up the majority of White PE professionals at 79 percent, with 86 percent at the managing-director level. By contrast, women who identify as ethnic and racial minorities were the least represented group among investment professionals across all levels. White professionals lead promotion rates into every level except principal (L3). The difference in promotion is most drastic at the managing-director level (L2), in which White professionals were more than 2.3 times more likely to be promoted than any other race or ethnicity. And once they make it to the top, White professionals has the lowest rates of attrition, trailing only Hispanic and Latino investing professionals in attrition rates at the principal level (L3) and managing-director level (L2).</p>
<h3>Firms with more ethnic and racial diversity at the top tend to have more-diverse talent pools</h3>
<p>Not all PE firms have struggled to attract and develop talent from ethnic and racial minorities. Leading firms have reached or are nearing representative levels, with 42 percent of investing talent identifying as ethnic or racial minorities, compared with 30 percent of the Canadian population and 41 percent of the US population.</p>
<p>Lagging firms, on the other hand, have almost no ethnic and racial diversity at senior levels. These challenges at the top are reflected throughout the organization, with only 23 percent of investing professionals at lagging firms identifying as ethnic and racial minorities.</p>
<p>Firms that lead the industry in ethnic and racial diversity have demonstrated that significant progress is possible, but there is still work to be done to make PE offices in the United States and Canada more representative. Black and Hispanic professionals remain underrepresented, even at firms that lead on ethnic and racial diversity. Fourteen percent of the US population is Black, and 19 percent is Hispanic,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5b9dcbbc-1bff-4a41-8246-148e18984ce8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5b9dcbbc-1bff-4a41-8246-148e18984ce8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">QuickFacts: United States population estimates, US Census Bureau, July 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> but even at leading firms, only 8 percent of managing directors are Black, and 9 percent are Hispanic.</p>
<h2>Institutional investors are asking more about DEI metrics</h2>
<p>When making funding decisions, institutional investors increasingly take PE firms DEI practices into account.</p>
<p>Institutional investors are broadening their view of DEI beyond the investment team and institutional investors now increasingly ask about DEI metrics within portfolio companies and their boards (Exhibit 7). This growing interest from institutional investors has encouraged PE firms to systematically track and report on these metrics, fueling momentum toward diversity and inclusion in the industry. As a partner at a North American PE fund put it, Data requests from LPs [limited partners] on diversity and inclusion have gone from zero in the 2000s to everyone asking about it today.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 7</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Approximately half of firms provide diversity data about their investing team, portfolio company, C-suite, and board." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20diversity%20in%20global%20private%20markets%202023/svgz-the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2023-ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Notably, some institutional investors track PE firms year-over-year improvements in diversity and inclusion as part of their DEI assessments. Forward-looking institutional investors have started to move beyond simply tracking DEI metrics and are beginning to set minimum thresholds on some metrics. For instance, one institutional investor in our sample requires PE firms to meet minimum racial- and gender-diversity thresholds before the institutional investor considers making an investment.</p>
<h3>Structural barriers for PE firms owned by ethnic and racial minorities and women</h3>
<p>Institutional investors are continuing to gather data on diversity inclusion. But are their allocations consistent with their stated priorities?</p>
<p>Institutional investors that participated in last years study said they would be willing to give more capital to more-diverse deal teams.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="08a6a6a7-8b60-4216-9099-c83976d2442e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="08a6a6a7-8b60-4216-9099-c83976d2442e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">QuickFacts: United States population estimates, US Census Bureau, July 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> However, institutional investors face challenges in making that promise a reality. As of 2021, PE firms owned by ethnic and racial minorities and women managed only 6 percent of total AUM in PE.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dcdefa1e-1004-4a23-b0a3-561a8baa35a3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dcdefa1e-1004-4a23-b0a3-561a8baa35a3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Knight diversity of asset managers research series: Industry</em>, Knight Foundation, December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> If diversity is high on institutional investors priority list, why dont minority-owned funds receive more capital?</p>
<p>The hurdle for minority- and women-owned funds is not their track record or the investing teams experience. The challenges are structural and make it harder for institutional investors to allocate to these firms. For instance, compared with their competitors, minority- and women-owned firms are smaller and newer on average. In the current macroeconomic environment, institutional investors are relying more on existing long-term relationships with general partners to weather the cycle, leaving even fewer slots for these firms to compete over. To connect with these firms, institutional investors would have to go through brokers or adjust their minimum allocation rules to directly invest in smaller raises.</p>
<p>As institutional investors continue to shape the future of private equity, their influence will be vital in ensuring that DEI remains top of mind. Through thoughtful capital allocation and continued focus on DEI metrics, institutional investors have the power to drive meaningful change in the sector, making PE more inclusive, more diverse, and ultimately more successful.</p>
<h2>From aspiration to action: Tangible steps toward a more diverse future</h2>
<p>Our study highlights that to achieve a more diverse, equitable, and inclusive industry, firms require additional internal actions and practices as well as external pressures. Strategies to retain and promote diverse talent within PE firms would need to coexist with a collaborative commitment from institutional investors to demand DEI metrics and support women- and minority-owned funds. Our discussion focuses on specific actions and regional considerations that can accelerate the path to greater diversity of talent within investing roles in private markets globally.</p>
<h3>Must-haves: A focus on retaining diverse talent and practices that accelerate the path to equity</h3>
<p>PE firms have made initial progress in diversifying their entry-level talent pipelines. To establish a more inclusive culture and move toward gender parity, those efforts would need to extend to the senior ranks. Its important for practices that promote diversity and inclusion to be embedded in every level of the organization. DEI should not be seen as just a recruitment initiative.</p>
<p>Key practices to implement include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li>analyzing attrition and promotion rates by gender, ethnicity, and race where possible, along with other measures of diversity, to shed light on firms effectiveness in retaining and promoting diverse talent</li>
    <li>developing intentional sponsorship and mentorship programs that can guide diverse talent, especially in midlevel roles</li>
    <li>establishing employee resource groups (ERGs) for diverse talent to offer safe spaces for interaction, discussion, and mutual support</li>
    <li>implementing more flexible HR policies, such as remote work, to cast a wider net for talent and improve inclusion for professionals from diverse backgrounds</li>
    <li>hosting unconscious-bias and conscious-inclusion training to minimize the impact of unconscious prejudices on decision-making processes</li>
    <li>creating intentional on-ramps and off-ramps for employees as they transition to and from parental leave or extended time off to help normalize these journeys</li>
</ul>
<p>These initiatives go beyond recruitment and are crucial in building an inclusive environment that not only welcomes diverse team members but also enables them to flourish and ascend the ranks. By committing to these practices, PE firms can nurture diversity throughout their organizations, from the entry level to top leadership.</p>
<hr>
<p>The road toward equity in PE is long, but a continued focus on actions that could accelerate progress can put the industrys aspirations within reach. Institutional investors can continue to reinforce the industrys commitment to DEI, and by acting on these commitments, PE firms can hone the edge that comes with diversity.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/pontus-averstad">Pontus Averstad</a></strong> and <strong><a href="/our-people/fredrik-dahlqvist">Fredrik Dahlqvist</a></strong> are senior partners in McKinseys Stockholm office; <strong>Eitan Lefkowitz</strong> is a consultant in the New Jersey office; <strong><a href="/our-people/alexandra-nee">Alexandra Nee</a></strong> is a partner in the Washington, DC, office, where <strong>Mohammed Shafi</strong> is a consultant; <strong><a href="/our-people/gary-pinshaw">Gary Pinshaw</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Sydney office; and <strong><a href="/our-people/david-quigley">David Quigley</a></strong> is a senior partner in the New York office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Alejandro Beltrn, Diana Ellsworth, Carlos Esber, Tim Ewing, Catherine Falls, James Gannon, Chris Gorman, Kori Hill, Alexis Howard, Gil Sander Joseph, Claudy Jules, Bruck Kebede, Drew Knapp, Connor Kramer, Alexis Krivkovich, Ju-Hon Kwek, Bola Lawrence, Robin Lore, Tess Mandoli, Emma Moriarty, Andrew Mullin, Suraya Narayan, Margret-Ann Natsis, Hilary Nguyen, Daniel Obed, Vivek Pandit, David Pinski, Luis Rivera, Nicole Robinson, Elise Sauve, Jennifer Schmidt, Jeanette Stock, Neha Verma, Monne Williams, Jackie Wong, and Lareina Yee for their contributions to this report.</p>
<p>The authors also wish to thank all the participating private equity firms and institutional investors, without whose participation these industry-wide benchmarks would not be possible.</p>
<p>We are appreciative of McKinsey and LeanIn.orgs Women in the Workplace study, which has informed the creation of this work.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The state of diversity in global private markets 2023","displayName":"The state of diversity in global private markets 2023","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"9e9f3961-5afe-4363-a758-187432a3735e","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The state of diversity in global private markets: 2023"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Private equity firms and institutional investors have intensified their focus on gender and ethnic diversity, but the road ahead remains long."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Private equity firms and institutional investors have intensified their focus on diversity, but the road ahead remains long."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-08-22T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOver the course of 2022,\u003c/strong\u003e the global private markets industry experienced a slowdown in fundraising and deal making because of rising interest rates and other factors. Despite the rocky year, private equity and alternative investments (hereafter PE) and alternative investments remain significant in the global economy. The industry now manages $11.7 trillion in assets, up from $8.0 trillion the previous year.[[footnote 1]] The financial power of PE reinforces the importance of understanding the composition of its talent, particularly the professionals who decide how this capital is deployed.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding on \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/the-state-of-diversity-in-global-private-markets-2022\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s 2022 report\u003c/a\u003e, this year\u0026rsquo;s report examines the diversity of talent in PE firms, which we will refer to simply as PE firms. Specifically, we examine the gender breakdown in every region in our study and look at ethnicity and race in the United States and Canada (for more on the research and analysis, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;About the study\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis year\u0026rsquo;s report centers on the following core research objectives:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eunderstand the current state of gender diversity globally, and ethnic and racial diversity in the US and Canada, for the PE industry\u0026mdash;specifically, which types of firms are leading and lagging on diverse talent\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ehow institutional investors influence the representation of diverse talent at PE firms, and the extent to which diversity matters to them\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ehighlighting the specific challenges facing different minority groups and identifying actions that can increase the diversity of talent in PE firms\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n[[Sidebar1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis report finds encouraging signs of progress in recent years. Diversity on investment committees (ICs) has ticked up, and the reporting of diversity metrics to institutional investors continues to grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStill, gaps remain, particularly regarding gender diversity in senior investing roles and uneven rates of progress for different ethnic and racial groups across roles and regions, and types of firms. Given the current pace of progress, it will be several decades before the PE industry achieves gender parity at the principal and managing-director levels.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eA global view on gender diversity in private equity and alternative investing\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is a popular assumption that PE is dominated by men, but the evidence reveals a more nuanced reality. As we noted last year, PE firms have almost achieved gender parity globally at the entry level. At the end of 2022, 48 percent of all entry-level roles in PE were held by women.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, women in PE are still underrepresented in leadership positions, with only 20 percent representation in managing-director roles (for more on job levels, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Job levels in private equity\u0026rdquo;). As Kelley King, senior vice president and chief DEI officer at HarbourVest, explained, \u0026ldquo;Identifying and attracting early-career diverse talent is not as challenging as finding later-career talent. As you ascend higher in the organization, the more patient and intentional firms need to be to reap the benefits of their DEI efforts.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWomen are well represented in most noninvesting roles, but gender parity remains distant in investing and operating roles\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDisaggregating the data into investing, operating, and other noninvesting roles (the latter of which we will refer to as noninvesting roles) reveals that women hold only 33 percent of entry-level investing roles, compared with 44 percent of operating roles and 59 percent of noninvesting roles at that level. Women are also underrepresented at the managing-director level (L2), with only 15 percent of managing-director-level investing roles (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eWomen in PE have made modest gains in investing roles over the course of 2022. The share of C-suite roles held by women globally increased by 3.5 percentage points over the past year to 17 percent at the end of 2022. Similarly, women\u0026rsquo;s representation in post-MBA investing associate (L5) roles improved by three percentage points. However, gender diversity at the managing-director level remained constant.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWomen in PE are slightly less represented in operating roles than in investing roles, with women holding only 25 percent of all operating roles. Notably, women in operations have achieved gender parity at the associate level (L5), with 52 percent of roles. However, gender diversity undergoes a steep decline at higher levels, with women holding just 21 percent of managing-director-level (L2) operating jobs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProgress is generally cause for optimism, but if the pace of progress doesn\u0026rsquo;t accelerate, the path to gender parity in the industry will be long. At the current rate of progress, reaching gender parity in investing roles at the managing-director level (L2) would take more than six decades. Achieving gender parity at the principal level (L3) would take more than three decades (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhile these numbers are sobering, the outlook is significantly brighter at the entry level. Based on current figures, the industry could reach gender parity at the analyst level (L6) and associate level (L5) within the next decade.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003ePromotion rates: Women in investing face a longer road\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn demanding PE careers, women find themselves navigating a longer route to reach the same milestones as their male colleagues. At almost every level, women in investing roles are promoted at significantly lower rates than men. \u003cspan style=\"line-height: 110%;\"\u003eGlobally, men in investing roles are about 50 percent more likely, on average, to be promoted than their female colleagues,\u003c/span\u003e a trend that persists across all levels in investing roles (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe largest gap affects promotions into the principal level (L3), with men 2.75 times more likely than women to be promoted. One contributor to this disparity may be limited sponsorship and mentorship for women at the vice president (VP) level. As the head of talent for a North American PE fund put it, \u0026ldquo;At that [middle] level is where we find a number of ethnic minorities and women who have really felt like the levels they are at have a sticky floor. They found that it\u0026rsquo;s really hard to get that next promotion. They feel left out. They haven\u0026rsquo;t received the kind of mentorship and the kind of apprenticeship that they\u0026rsquo;re really going to need or the sponsorship to get promoted.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe road to meaningful progress will likely be long. However, there\u0026rsquo;s a bright spot: the promotion gap at the managing-director level (L2) shrank in 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eSignificant differences in representation between leading and lagging firms\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome firms have made noteworthy strides on the diversity of their talent pool, so much so that the industry\u0026rsquo;s global average of women in 15 percent of investing managing-director roles looks paltry by comparison. Leading firms had women in 45 percent of managing-director (L2) roles as the end of 2022. These firms also had significantly higher proportions of women at every level and overall had women in 38 percent of their investing roles, compared with the global average of 25 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterestingly, firms that were leaders in gender diversity (as indicated by relatively high proportions of women in managing-director\u0026nbsp;roles) also retained women at higher rates than the industry average. However, firms that lagged on gender diversity showed significantly higher attrition in 2022 among women in investing. These firms in our sample did not have women in managing-director\u0026nbsp;(L2) investing roles and had only 17 percent women in investing roles overall compared to the 25 percent global benchmark. Furthermore, these firms\u0026rsquo; attrition rates for women in investing were 1.7 times higher, at 27 percent, than the global average over the course of 2022 (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eFor investing roles, our findings suggest a correlation between the representation of women at the top and higher overall gender representation, as well as between lack of women at the top and their ability to retain women at all levels of investing roles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur findings on gender diversity over time also highlight the feasibility of substantial progress when decision makers deploy effective strategies. Indeed, the results of our study show that not all PE firms are equal when it comes to cultures that support diverse talent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDifferent regions have different timelines to gender parity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe timelines to achieving gender parity vary by region. For instance, despite advances, Europe still faces significant challenges related to women\u0026rsquo;s representation at senior levels. At its current pace, Europe would require more than six decades to reach gender parity at senior levels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy contrast, based on the rate of recent progress, the Americas are the furthest from achieving gender parity at middle and junior levels for investing roles. The situation is notably different in the Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific region, which has done the most to close the gender gap at middle and senior levels recently (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eA concerning trend has emerged over the past two years: gender representation has seen a minor decrease in the Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific region at the associate level (L5). Although this decline starts from a relatively high base, it indicates the need for ongoing efforts to maintain a diverse talent pipeline that can help the industry achieve gender parity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEthnic and racial diversity in private equity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsistent with our past findings, ethnic and racial minorities in PE face similar underrepresentation as women. At nearly every level, investing roles have lower ethnic and racial diversity than noninvesting and operating-partner roles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research data from the United States and Canada shows that ethnic and racial minorities represent only 20 percent of managing-director-level investing professionals (Exhibit 6). For context, people who identify as ethnic and racial minorities account for 30 percent of the Canadian population and 41 percent of the US population.[[footnote 2]] However, we found positive progress in ethnic and racial diversity in ICs in 2022. Ethnic and racial minorities represented 18 percent of investment committee members, nearly matching the ethnic and racial diversity of managing directors (L2) that year.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe improvement in the diversity of talent in investment committees over the course of 2022 may be the result of new requirements for PE firms to disclose C-suite- and investment-committee-level diversity data to prospective investors. The chief HR officer of a midsize PE firm headquartered in North America referred to this as \u0026ldquo;a standard part of the due diligence questionnaire these days.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInvestment professionals who identify as White held 70 percent of all investing roles and 80 percent of managing-director\u0026nbsp;roles. As of 2022, White men made up the majority of White PE professionals at 79 percent, with 86 percent at the managing-director\u0026nbsp;level. By contrast, women who identify as ethnic and racial minorities were the least represented group among investment professionals across all levels. White professionals lead promotion rates into every level except principal (L3). The difference in promotion is most drastic at the managing-director\u0026nbsp;level (L2), in which White professionals were more than 2.3 times more likely to be promoted than any other race or ethnicity. And once they make it to the top, White professionals has the lowest rates of attrition, trailing only Hispanic and Latino investing professionals in attrition rates at the principal level (L3) and managing-director\u0026nbsp;level (L2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFirms with more ethnic and racial diversity at the top tend to have more-diverse talent pools\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot all PE firms have struggled to attract and develop talent from ethnic and racial minorities. Leading firms have reached or are nearing representative levels, with 42 percent of investing talent identifying as ethnic or racial minorities, compared with 30 percent of the Canadian population and 41 percent of the US population.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLagging firms, on the other hand, have almost no ethnic and racial diversity at senior levels. These challenges at the top are reflected throughout the organization, with only 23 percent of investing professionals at lagging firms identifying as ethnic and racial minorities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirms that lead the industry in ethnic and racial diversity have demonstrated that significant progress is possible, but there is still work to be done to make PE offices in the United States and Canada more representative. Black and Hispanic professionals remain underrepresented, even at firms that lead on ethnic and racial diversity. Fourteen percent of the US population is Black, and 19 percent is Hispanic,[[footnote 3]] but even at leading firms, only 8 percent of managing directors are Black, and 9 percent are Hispanic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eInstitutional investors are asking more about DEI metrics\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen making funding decisions, institutional investors increasingly take PE firms\u0026rsquo; DEI practices into account.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstitutional investors are broadening their view of DEI beyond the investment team and institutional investors now increasingly ask about DEI metrics within portfolio companies and their boards (Exhibit 7). This growing interest from institutional investors has encouraged PE firms to systematically track and report on these metrics, fueling momentum toward diversity and inclusion in the industry. As a partner at a North American PE fund put it, \u0026ldquo;Data requests from LPs [limited partners] on diversity and inclusion have gone from zero in the 2000s to everyone asking about it today.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 7]]\n\u003cp\u003eNotably, some institutional investors track PE firms\u0026rsquo; year-over-year improvements in diversity and inclusion as part of their DEI assessments. Forward-looking institutional investors have started to move beyond simply tracking DEI metrics and are beginning to set minimum thresholds on some metrics. For instance, one institutional investor in our sample requires PE firms to meet minimum racial- and gender-diversity thresholds before the institutional investor considers making an investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eStructural barriers for PE firms owned by ethnic and racial minorities and women\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstitutional investors are continuing to gather data on diversity inclusion. But are their allocations consistent with their stated priorities?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstitutional investors that participated in last year\u0026rsquo;s study said they would be willing to give more capital to more-diverse deal teams.[[footnote 4]] However, institutional investors face challenges in making that promise a reality. As of 2021, PE firms owned by ethnic and racial minorities and women managed only 6 percent of total AUM in PE.[[footnote 5]] If diversity is high on institutional investors\u0026rsquo; priority list, why don\u0026rsquo;t minority-owned funds receive more capital?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe hurdle for minority- and women-owned funds is not their track record or the investing team\u0026rsquo;s experience. The challenges are structural and make it harder for institutional investors to allocate to these firms. For instance, compared with their competitors, minority- and women-owned firms are smaller and newer on average. In the current macroeconomic environment, institutional investors are relying more on existing long-term relationships with general partners to weather the cycle, leaving even fewer slots for these firms to compete over. To connect with these firms, institutional investors would have to go through brokers or adjust their minimum allocation rules to directly invest in smaller raises.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs institutional investors continue to shape the future of private equity, their influence will be vital in ensuring that DEI remains top of mind. Through thoughtful capital allocation and continued focus on DEI metrics, institutional investors have the power to drive meaningful change in the sector, making PE more inclusive, more diverse, and ultimately more successful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFrom aspiration to action: Tangible steps toward a more diverse future\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur study highlights that to achieve a more diverse, equitable, and inclusive industry, firms require additional internal actions and practices as well as external pressures. Strategies to retain and promote diverse talent within PE firms would need to coexist with a collaborative commitment from institutional investors to demand DEI metrics and support women- and minority-owned funds. Our discussion focuses on specific actions and regional considerations that can accelerate the path to greater diversity of talent within investing roles in private markets globally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMust-haves: A focus on retaining diverse talent and practices that accelerate the path to equity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePE firms have made initial progress in diversifying their entry-level talent pipelines. To establish a more inclusive culture and move toward gender parity, those efforts would need to extend to the senior ranks. It\u0026rsquo;s important for practices that promote diversity and inclusion to be embedded in every level of the organization. DEI should not be seen as just a recruitment initiative.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKey practices to implement include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eanalyzing attrition and promotion rates by gender, ethnicity, and race where possible, along with other measures of diversity, to shed light on firms\u0026rsquo; effectiveness in retaining and promoting diverse talent\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003edeveloping intentional sponsorship and mentorship programs that can guide diverse talent, especially in midlevel roles\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eestablishing employee resource groups (ERGs) for diverse talent to offer safe spaces for interaction, discussion, and mutual support\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eimplementing more flexible HR policies, such as remote work, to cast a wider net for talent and improve inclusion for professionals from diverse backgrounds\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ehosting unconscious-bias and conscious-inclusion training to minimize the impact of unconscious prejudices on decision-making processes\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ecreating intentional on-ramps and off-ramps for employees as they transition to and from parental leave or extended time off to help normalize these journeys\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese initiatives go beyond recruitment and are crucial in building an inclusive environment that not only welcomes diverse team members but also enables them to flourish and ascend the ranks. By committing to these practices, PE firms can nurture diversity throughout their organizations, from the entry level to top leadership.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe road toward equity in PE is long, but a continued focus on actions that could accelerate progress can put the industry\u0026rsquo;s aspirations within reach. Institutional investors can continue to reinforce the industry\u0026rsquo;s commitment to DEI, and by acting on these commitments, PE firms can hone the edge that comes with our second annual report, we build on the insights and findings from our inaugural report in 2022, as well as on prior McKinsey research on diversity in the workplace. This research explores diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) in the global private-markets industry, with a focus on private equity and alternative investment firms (PE) and institutional investors. We aim to make this the largest study of gender diversity and ethnic and racial diversity in the global private markets industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis year\u0026rsquo;s survey covers 66 discrete PE firms and institutional investors around the world. We also conducted interviews with several industry leaders to supplement the survey data we received from their firms. Participating firms directly employ more than 60,000 people globally and range from megafirms with more than $100 billion in assets under management (AUM) to smaller funds with less than $5 billion in AUM. Collectively, participating PE firms manage more than $6 trillion, and participating institutional investors manage more than $5 trillion in AUM.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven the limitations of data collection, this report largely focuses on gender diversity globally and ethnic and racial diversity in private market firms with offices in the United States and Canada. We recognize there are several other categories that contribute to employee diversity and hope to broaden the categories we examine in future research as private market firms collect more diversity data on their employee base.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"About the study"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe language we use to classify jobs in private equity (PE) has not changed from last year's. In descending order of seniority, the roles are as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eL1. C-level executives or fund heads. We refer to this level as the C-level or C-suite.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eL2. Managing directors or partners. We refer to jobs at this level as managing directors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eL3.
